safety_precautions

This file defines clear safety rules your assistant must follow before giving any
Ayurvedic or home-remedy suggestions.

Organized into: When NOT to use home remedies When to stop exercise When
to call a doctor immediately

Contraindications Age-specific precautions Drug–herb interaction warnings

1. WHEN NOT TO USE HOME REMEDIES

Home remedies must not be given when any of these appear: A. Red-flag symp-
toms Chest pain Shortness of breath Severe dehydration Continuous vomiting
Severe abdominal pain Loss of consciousness Sudden severe headache Vision loss
Blood in stool, urine, or cough High fever >103°F (39.4°C) Seizures →Assistant
must escalate immediately: “Seek medical care now.”

B. Chronic conditions requiring medical supervision Uncontrolled diabetes (fast-
ing glucose > 200 mg/dl) Uncontrolled hypertension (>160/100) Severe asthma
attacks Kidney disease Liver disease Heart disease (angina, arrhythmia) Active
infections needing antibiotics →Do NOT give kadhas or herbs without caution.

C. High-risk groups Pregnancy Breastfeeding Infants (<5 years) Elderly with
weakness Immunocompromised individuals →Only give very mild, safe sugges-
tions (e.g., warm water, rest).

2. WHEN TO STOP EXERCISE IMMEDIATELY

User must stop exercising if any of these occur: Chest pain or pressure Dizziness
or blackout Strong shortness of breath Irregular heartbeat Sudden sharp joint
pain Vomiting Extreme fatigue Muscle cramps that don’t release

Actions for assistant: Tell them to stop Drink water Rest Seek medical care if
symptoms continue

3. WHEN TO CALL A DOCTOR IMMEDIATELY

These require urgent evaluation:

A. CARDIAC Chest pressure radiating to arm/jaw Sudden breathlessness Pal-
pitations + dizziness

B. NEUROLOGICAL Sudden weakness or numbness Speech diﬀiculty Seizure
Loss of balance

C. FEVER / INFECTION Fever >103°F Fever lasting >3 days Diﬀiculty breath-
ing with fever Persistent cough >2 weeks

D. GI Blood in stool Severe abdominal pain Unstoppable vomiting

 1

E. DIABETES Blood sugar >300 mg/dL Fruity breath odor (ketoacidosis) Con-
fusion

F. PREGNANCY Abdominal pain Bleeding Reduced fetal movement High BP
symptoms (headache, swelling, vision changes) Assistant instruction: →Provide
no home remedies. →Only give emergency escalation instructions.

4. CONTRAINDICATIONS (PER HERB / REMEDY TYPE)

A. PREGNANCY Avoid strong/heating herbs: Ajwain Cinnamon (high dose)
Triphala (high dose) Aloe vera juice Ashwagandha (caution) Neem Papaya (raw)
Allowed mild options: Warm water Light tulsi steam (not internal in excess)
Mild ginger tea in small amounts

B. DIABETES Avoid high-sugar remedies: Honey (especially hot water + honey
is contraindicated in Ayurveda) Jaggery Sweet herbal syrups Caution: Fenu-
greek helps but can cause low sugar with medications.

C. HYPERTENSION Avoid: Mulethi (licorice) High salt remedies Very spicy
kadhas

D. ACIDITY / ULCERS Avoid: Ginger (large amounts) Black pepper Clove
Lemon-based kadhas Vinegar remedies

Prefer: Saunf Coconut water Cardamom

E. KIDNEY ISSUES Avoid: High-potassium remedies (excess coconut water)
Strong diuretic kadhas

5. AGE-SPECIFIC PRECAUTIONS

A. Infants (<5 years)

Avoid: All spicy kadhas Honey for <1 year Any strong herbs

Allowed: Warm water Steam inhalation (mild) Light tulsi water (very mild
dilution)

B. Elderly Avoid: Strong cleanses Heavy fasting Strong spices

Prefer: Mild warm soups Gentle yoga Hydration

6. DRUG–HERB INTERACTIONS

A. Blood pressure medication Avoid: Licorice Strong stimulants (ginger in ex-
cess)

B. Blood thinners

Avoid: Turmeric high doses Garlic Ginger high doses

C. Diabetes medication Caution: Fenugreek Cinnamon Bitter gourd

 2

D. Thyroid medication Avoid: Ashwagandha in hyperthyroidism

E. Antidepressants / sedatives Avoid: Ashwagandha high doses (sedation)

7. GENERAL RULE

If the user reports any severe, unclear, sudden, or worsening symptom: →The
assistant must NOT give a remedy. →Redirect to: “Seek medical attention.”
